Tutorial.description: More about the logic system and its blocks

Start.Content:
Welcome to the Advanced Logic Tutorial.
In the basic tutorial, you were introduced to the activation block, which is the most vital block in the system. Here you will learn about all the other blocks used in logic and its triggers.

StateA.Content: As you now know, you can link blocks together to make a chain to remote control the block at the end. You can build a lot more complex things though. This is where the NOT, OR, AND, and DELAY blocks come into play.

StateB.Content:
Every one of these blocks can be linked just like the activation blocks.
The simplest one to understand is probably the NOT block. What it does is simply inverting an incoming signal from 'on' to 'off' and vice versa.

StateC.Content: The more complicated blocks are the AND and OR blocks. Those blocks will need multiple inputs. The inputs can by any logic blocks, even OR and AND themselves.

StateD.Content: AND will look at all the blocks that are connected to it and only output the 'on' signal when ALL of the receiving signals are 'on'.

StateE.Content: OR will look at all the blocks that are connected to it and only output the 'on' signal when ONE or more of the receiving signals is 'on'.

StateF.Content:
Now to the delay block. The delay block takes a signal on/off and outputs it just like the activation block.
However, it will not do this immediately but with a delay.

StateG.Content: The delay block enables players to build looped systems like clocks, and many more complex circuits.

StateH.Content: There are several internet sites to look up basic logic gates. You can rebuild these in StarMade.

End.Content: This concludes the Advanced Logic Tutorial. Thanks for reading, and thanks for playing StarMade!
